name: Colombo
fun_fact: Fun fact: Sri Lanka is the world's fourth-largest tea producer, and tea accounts for over $1.3 billion in exports. British planter James Taylor introduced tea in 1867 after coffee plantations were devastated by fungal disease. He's still remembered as the 'Father of Ceylon Tea.' Also, 78% of travelers to Sri Lanka in 2024 came specifically to experience the street food culture!

hero_dishes.name: Hoppers (Appa)
hero_dishes.description: Bowl-shaped pancakes made from fermented rice flour batter. Crispy and lacy on the edges, soft and spongy in the middle. Egg hoppers feature a soft-cooked egg cracked into the center during cooking.
hero_dishes.origin_story: An ancient Sri Lankan breakfast staple dating back centuries, using fermented rice flour and coconut milk. The unique bowl shape comes from swirling the batter in a small wok-like pan. Each family has their own fermentation secrets passed down through generations.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Green Cabin (rumored to have the best hoppers in Colombo). Podi kade (small street shops) throughout the city serve fresh hoppers for LKR 150-300 (USD 0.50-1.00). Best eaten for breakfast or dinner, paired with lunu miris (spicy onion-chili paste) and coconut sambol.

hero_dishes.name: Kottu Roti
hero_dishes.description: Chopped roti stir-fried on a hot griddle with vegetables, egg, and choice of chicken, beef, or cheese. The rhythmic metallic clanging of blades chopping the roti is an iconic street food sound across Sri Lanka.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Created as a way to use leftover roti, kottu evolved into a beloved national dish. The theatrical preparation - chefs rapidly chopping ingredients with metal blades creating a percussion-like rhythm - became part of the experience. Each chef has a unique chopping pattern.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Hotel de New Pilawoos (Pilawoos) is considered THE iconic place for kottu in Colombo - a no-frills restaurant frequented by locals. Remember: kottu is strictly a dinner-time dish, only available after 5 PM. The sound of kottu being made draws crowds of hungry diners.

hero_dishes.name: String Hoppers (Idiyappam)
hero_dishes.description: Delicate rice noodle cakes made by pressing rice flour dough through a mold to create thin noodles, then steamed into circular patties. Light and airy texture.
hero_dishes.origin_story: A Tamil-influenced dish that became a Sri Lankan breakfast staple. The art of creating perfectly thin, even strands requires skill and practice. Traditionally made fresh each morning by hand.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Podi kade (street shops) serve fresh string hoppers for breakfast with coconut sambol and light dhal curry. Found throughout Colombo's neighborhoods, especially in Pettah and near Galle Face.

signature_drinks.name: Ceylon Tea
signature_drinks.description: World-renowned black tea grown in Sri Lanka's hill country. Ceylon tea is characterized by altitude - low-grown (full-bodied), mid-grown (balanced), or high-grown (delicate and aromatic). The six famous regions are Galle, Ratnapura, Kandy, Nuwara Eliya, Dimbula, and Uva.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Tea is mandatory at breakfast - Sri Lankans start the day with tea, then have another with breakfast. Afternoon tea time (inherited from British colonial era) is still observed - families gather for tea and biscuits around 3-4 PM. Served strong, with milk and sugar. On festive occasions like New Year, tea is accompanied by traditional sweets like Kevum, Kokis, and Aluwa.

signature_drinks.name: King Coconut Water (Thambili)
signature_drinks.description: Juice from orange king coconuts (unique to Sri Lanka), naturally sweet and rich in electrolytes. More orange in color and sweeter than regular coconut water.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Drunk fresh from roadside vendors who chop the top off with a machete and add a straw. Consumed throughout the day to cool down in tropical heat. Considered healthier and more refreshing than regular coconut water.

food_culture_notes: Sri Lankan cuisine is characterized by bold spices - cinnamon, cardamom, cloves, curry leaves, and chillies dominate
Rice and curry is the foundation of Sri Lankan meals - rice surrounded by multiple curry dishes, sambols, and papadums
Pettah Market is the epicenter of Colombo food culture - a sensory overload of spice vendors, street food stalls, and fresh produce
Galle Face Green becomes a street food paradise at sunset (5 PM onwards) with vendors selling isso wade (shrimp fritters), greasy snacks, grilled chicken, and pickled wood apples
Podi kade (small street shops) are the authentic eating experience - run-down no-name joints with window displays of pastries, serving hoppers, string hoppers, and kottu at rock-bottom prices
90% of tea is still produced using traditional hand-picking methods, though modern CTC techniques were introduced in the 1990s
Street food culture is the main attraction: 78.347% of 2024 travelers came specifically to experience local street food

landmarks: Jami Ul-Alfar Mosque (Red Mosque) - candy-striped red and white mosque in Pettah, built 1909
Galle Face Green - 5-hectare oceanside urban park stretching 500m along the coast, used for kite flying, cricket, and evening street food
Khan Clock Tower - tall monument marking the entrance to Pettah Market
Pettah Market - one of Sri Lanka's oldest and busiest markets with colonial-era architecture
Galle Face Hotel - historic colonial hotel overlooking the ocean (rugby's first match in Ceylon played at Galle Face Green in 1879)
atmosphere: Chaotic energy of Pettah Market - vendors calling out, tuk-tuks weaving through crowds, spice aromas
Rhythmic clanging of kottu chefs chopping roti on hot griddles
Sunset gatherings at Galle Face Green - families, couples, kite flyers, and food vendors
Tuk-tuks (auto-rickshaws) everywhere in bright colors with decorative details
Fresh seafood being grilled on beach-side grills
Tea culture - families gathering for afternoon tea with traditional sweets
Tropical heat and monsoon humidity, palm trees swaying in ocean breeze
colors: Red and white candy stripes of Jami Ul-Alfar Mosque
Bright spice piles at Pettah Market - turmeric yellow, red chili, green cardamom, brown cinnamon
Ocean blues and greens of Galle Face waterfront
Colorful tuk-tuks - yellow, green, red, decorated with patterns
Golden-brown hoppers and kottu being cooked
Vibrant tropical greens of palm trees and monsoon vegetation
unique_modern: Pettah Floating Markets - 92 trade stalls on boats at Beira Lake, selling local produce and handicrafts
Sea Street gold market - hundreds of jewelry shops in a single street where all of Sri Lanka comes to buy gold
Kite flying tradition at Galle Face Green every evening
Royal-Thomian cricket match tradition dating to 1879 (first played at Galle Face)
Colonial history: Dutch laid out Galle Face Green for cannon fire lines against Portuguese, later became promenade for ladies in 1856
Tea tourism: visitors can tour plantations, meet pickers, see traditional hand-processing (withering, rolling, drying)
Historical quirk: Kayman's Gate named because Dutch stocked crocodiles in Beira Lake to prevent slave escapes
